title-group.article-title: Collective Personality Effects on Group Citizenship Behavior
title-group.subtitle: Do Diverse Groups Benefit More?

author-notes.corresp: Marie-Élène Roberge, Department of Management and Marketing, Northeastern Illinois University, 5500 St. Louis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60625, USA Email: m-roberge@neiu.edu

abstract.p: This study examines the interaction of collective personality (i.e., the Big Five traits) and national diversity on group interpersonal citizenship behavior. Groups composed of diverse nationalities are theorized to manifest fewer initial shared understandings, enabling them to obtain more benefits than homogeneous groups from collective personality traits that promote better quality relationships. In a study of university students assigned to 15 nationally homogeneous groups (n = 61) and 20 nationally heterogeneous groups (n = 79), groups scoring higher on openness to experience, agreeableness, or extraversion show more interpersonal citizenship behavior. The effects of openness to experience, agreeableness, and extraversion are enhanced for nationally diverse teams. Moreover, neuroticism had no direct effect on interpersonal citizenship behavior; its interaction with national diversity yielded reversed effects. Neuroticism was negatively related to citizenship behavior in diverse groups and positively related to it in homogeneous groups. Theoretical and practical implications are developed for small group situations where diversity issues may threaten relationship quality.

body.p: The shared or collective qualities of groups contribute to their effectiveness in myriad ways. Collective intelligence enhances group performance beyond the impact of its members’ IQ across an array of tasks (Woolley-Williams, Chabris, Pentland, Hashmi, & Malone, 2010). Shared memory of what each member does well helps groups learn faster and perform better (Ellis, 2006). Groups in which certain collective personality traits dominate perform better on a host of tasks (Hofmann & Jones, 2005; Mohammed & Angell, 2003; Moynihan & Peterson, 2001). Collective personality refers to behavioral regularities within a group (Hofmann & Jones, 2005; Stewart, 2003). Particular collective personality traits from the widely applied Big Five personality model have been found to affect group performance (Bell, 2007; Hofmann & Jones, 2005; Zoogah, Boghossian, & Sawyer, 2010). Moreover, a body of research including several meta-analyses finds consistent relationships between personality and individual-level interpersonal citizenship behavior (Dalal, 2005; Hurtz & Donovan, 2000; Lapierre & Hackett, 2007; LePine, Erez, & Johnson, 2002). No study has yet examined this relationship at the group level.

The present study makes two contributions. First, it extends research on collective personality by examining its direct effects on group interpersonal citizenship behavior. Group interpersonal citizenship behavior refers to prosocial interpersonal behaviors within a group. Although such behavior can be an important contributor to overall effectiveness, only a few empirical studies exist at the group level (Chattopadhyay, 1999; Munyon, Hochwarter, Perrewé, & Ferris, 2010). Second, this study investigates how demographic diversity, specifically national diversity, affects the effect of collective personality on group citizenship behavior. By experimentally manipulating group composition, we investigate whether and how diversity in member nationality interacts with five collective personality traits (i.e., openness to experience, extraversion, conscientiousness, agreeableness, and neuroticism) to affect the group’s interpersonal citizenship behavior. Although research exists on the interaction effects of group personality and diversity on group effectiveness (Homan et al., 2008; Kearney, Gebert, & Voelpel, 2009, Zoogah et al., 2010), the present study is the first to investigate the role of national diversity. Given the globalization of contemporary organizations, knowledge about the interaction effects of group personality and national diversity is especially relevant.

sec.title: Literature Review
sec.p: To develop this study’s hypotheses, we first review collective personality, diversity, and group interpersonal citizenship behavior.

sec.title: Collective Personality
sec.p: Collective personality refers to the behavioral regularities manifest in a unit as a whole (Hofmann & Jones, 2005). Groups can be characterized by the same terms individuals are described, for example, as aggressive or accepting, open or friendly. The construct of collective personality provides insight into underlying psychological processes that can affect the effectiveness of a unit, group, or organization. At the organizational level, collective personality has been characterized as “recurring patterns of behavior of multiple organizational members involved in performing organizational tasks” (Feldman & Rafaeli, 2002, p. 311). At the group level, it is used to represent “informal rules that groups adopt to regulate and regularize group member behavior” (Feldman, 1984, p. 47). We note, however, that these definitions overlap other well-established constructs such as organizational culture (Martin, 1992), routines (Cohen & Bacdayan, 1994), and behavioral norms (Cooke & Rousseau, 1988). Such behavioral regularities typically emerge over time in collectives as their members interact with each other. However, behavioral regularities are often absent from newly formed groups. In new or emergent situations where collective structures are absent, weak, or ambiguous, collective personality can emerge from the traits individuals bring to the situation, particularly if these traits are sufficient in magnitude to form a basis for collective action (Mischel, 2004; Weick, 1995). The present study focuses on newly formed groups as a context for investigating whether within-group regularities can arise out of the personalities of their members.

Collective personality can facilitate or impede the development of positive intragroup behaviors. When collective personality traits foster friendship, supportive social relationships, and conflict resolution, the group is more likely to develop interpersonal citizenship behaviors. When the collective personality traits are antisocial in nature, interpersonal citizenship is less likely. Such effects are likely to be enhanced in diverse groups, especially when newly formed, as engendering member cooperation and mutual support can be difficult. Homogeneous groups are able to capitalize on common identity and shared attributions absent in heterogeneous groups, and thus have an advantage in promoting cooperation (Gaertner & Dovidio, 2000). We posit that group diversity, specifically diversity in nationality, interacts with collective personality in promoting or impeding the member support and mutual aid that constitutes group interpersonal citizenship. As such, collective personality traits that focus on building quality relationships among members are expected to have a stronger effect on group interpersonal citizenship behavior in heterogeneous groups than in homogeneous groups. Collective personality traits that promote mutual support and aid in diverse groups can compensate for their lack of shared member attributes as a basis for cooperation. In a subsequent section, we develop theory linking each collective personality trait and their interaction with national diversity in affecting within-group interpersonal citizenship behavior.

sec.title: Diversity
sec.p: Diversity has been defined at various conceptual levels (Roberge & van Dick, 2010). Typically, it is defined as differences between individuals on any attribute that may lead to the perception that another person is different from the self (Triandis, Kurowski, & Gelfand, 1994; van Knippenberg, De Dreu, & Homan, 2004; Williams & O’Reilly, 1998). Group or team diversity typically refers to within-group differences in demographics (Pelled, Eisenhardt, & Xin, 1999). Over time, researchers have expanded their attention to other bases of group diversity: informational/functional characteristics (e.g., job, function, expertise, and status), personality traits, sexual orientations, and mental and physical health and abilities (e.g., Roberge & van Dick, 2010; Shore et al., 2009).

The present study focuses on a form of group cultural diversity, defined as “the representation, in one social system, of people with distinctly different group affiliations of cultural significance” (Cox, 1994, p. 6). In particular, it investigates national diversity by contrasting multicultural teams composed of people born in different countries (heterogeneous condition) with teams whose members were born in the same country (homogeneous condition). This approach to diversity as an attribute of a group and it is consistent with that articulated by Nkomo and Cox (1996): “a mixture of people with different group identities within the same social system” (p. 339). All variables are conceptualized at the group level.

Despite the increasing diversity within organizations (Cox, 1994), a condition many organizations actively promote, cultural diversity in itself tends to impede group effectiveness. Other things being equal, a diverse workforce is prone to group conflicts and misunderstandings that, in turn, can lower the quality of organizational communication, employee satisfaction, and organizational citizenship behavior within a group, while increasing counterproductive work behavior and turnover (Shore et al., 2009; van Knippenberg & Schippers, 2007; Williams & O’Reilly, 1998).

Effects vary with the nature of group diversity. Positive outcomes are reported where diversity occurs along informational-related dimensions such as education, occupation, or functional background (Jehn, Northcraft, & Neale, 1999; Pelled, Eisenhardt, & Xin, 1999; Wanous & Youtz, 1986). Diversity in personality, however, tends to be associated with poor group performance (Barrick, Stewart, Neubert, & Mount, 1998; Kristof-Brown, Barrick, & Stevens, 2005; see Joshi, Liao, & Jackson, 2006, for an exception). A meta-analysis on the effects of cultural diversity in team effectiveness found that its effects vary depending on contextual variables such as task complexity and structural aspects of the team (Stahl, Maznevski, Voigt, & Jonsen, 2010). The effects of diversity on team outcomes depend both on the nature of diversity and task context, which in turn can aid or impair outcomes.

The present study focuses on within-group diversity in nationality. This form of diversity in itself is likely to impede group functioning unless circumstances and group efforts overcome the challenges that national diversity can create for a group. The basis for these challenges is founded on theories of social identity (Tajfel & Turner, 1986) and self-categorization (Turner, Hogg, Oakes, Reicher, & Wetherell, 1987). Social identity theory posits that interactions among group members who differ in nationality activate social categorization within the group. Social categorization is the differentiation of in-group others, who are subjectively similar to self, from out-group others, who are subjectively dissimilar to self. It entails interpreting the actions of others in terms of pre-existing beliefs associated with ethnicity or other attributes. Categorization accounts for the tendency of people in heterogeneous groups to experience stereotyping. It also makes an individual’s own social identity salient in his or her thoughts and experiences within the group (van Knippenberg et al., 2004). Social categorization leads to reduced interaction and communication among parties with a resultant adverse impact on group performance (van Knippenberg et al., 2004). As such, a group’s national diversity can be expected to keep members from willingly helping each other or going an extra mile to aid their group’s performance.

sec.title: Group Interpersonal Citizenship Behavior
sec.p: Group and organizational effectiveness are likely to be enhanced when employees go above or beyond the call of duty to assist fellow workers and achieve collective goals. Smith, Organ, and Near (1983) labeled this behavior as organizational citizenship behavior (OCB). OCB is “individual behavior that is discretionary, not directly or explicitly recognized by the formal reward system, and that in aggregate promotes the effectiveness of the organization” (Organ, 1988, p. 4).

Citizenship behavior reflects several forms of conduct that employees may not perform equally. Its forms differ in terms of their primary intended beneficiary or target (Williams & Anderson, 1991): OCBs targeted at individuals (OCB-I) versus OCBs targeted at organizations (OCB-O). A meta-analysis by Dalal (2005) found a true-score correlation of 0.64 between OCB-I and OCB-O, indicating that the two higher order dimensions of OCB are related yet distinct. Evidence for the distinctiveness of OCB-I and OCB-O is supported by a recent meta-analysis on the effects of leader–member exchange (LMX) on OCB. Ilies, Nahrgang, and Morgeson (2007) found that LMX, as an interpersonal exchange variable, is more strongly associated with OCB-I than with OCB-O.

The present study focuses on within-group interpersonal citizenship behavior where individuals act to benefit their fellow group members. Interpersonal citizenship behavior involves providing assistance for those who need help and respect for other people’s perspectives. These behaviors are related to but distinct from work group performance (Podsakoff & MacKenzie, 1997).

Interpersonal citizenship behavior differs from task performance by virtue of its voluntary nature. Citizenship is less likely to be mandated by the job or higher authorities (Organ, 1988). Instead, individuals use their discretion in deciding whether to provide these extrarole contributions. In so doing, individuals also determine which forms of citizenship they provide. In contrast to task performance, interpersonal citizenship behavior is undertaken and likely only when the individual possesses the skills and ability to make a particular extrarole contribution. Thus, a coworker with a car but no technical skills may help a colleague by driving him home, but not necessarily by fixing his computer. Although individuals may strive to demonstrate task-related behaviors regardless of their capabilities, the form a given person’s citizenship behaviors take tends to reflect his or her existing capacities.

Interpersonal citizenship behavior becomes increasingly important where teams are concerned. Teamwork imposes interdependence on individuals creating greater need for shared information, understanding, and interpersonal support in performing tasks (Janz, Colquitt, & Noe, 1997). Other things being equal, interdependent individuals are more prone to conflict than are more independent actors. Interpersonal citizenship among team members, by virtue of the support they provide each other, facilitates both task accomplishment and maintains team member willingness to contribute to the team and each other (Van Dyne & LePine, 1998). We focus on group interpersonal citizenship behavior because it represents a facet of OCB critical to teamwork. In general, diversity is likely to reduce interpersonal citizenship behavior by promoting conflicts that erode members’ goodwill. However, diverse groups stand to benefit by the conditions that ultimately promote interpersonal citizenship behavior, as it suggests that the interpersonal challenges associated with diverse groups have been overcome. The present research examines ways in which collective factors, specifically collective personality, can enable diversity to promote group-level interpersonal citizenship behavior.

sec.title: Hypotheses
sec.p: Collective personality, operationalized by averaging the Big Five traits, is known to contribute to group performance (Zoogah et al., 2010), but it remains unknown whether collective personality is related to OCB. In the present study, these traits (i.e., openness to experience, agreeableness, conscientiousness, neuroticism, and extraversion) are investigated in combination with national diversity to identify their impact on a form of OCB associated with relationship quality, that is, group-level interpersonal citizenship behavior. In developing our hypotheses, we pay careful attention to the underlying dynamics associated with each trait. These dynamics take particular forms in group settings, and we propose that these are amplified in nationally diverse groups.

sec.title: Group Openness to Experience
sec.p: Openness to experience is the willingness to explore, tolerate, and consider new and unfamiliar ideas and experiences (McCrae & Costa, 1987). People who score high on openness to experience are less likely to be dogmatic, more willing to consider different opinions, more open to all kind of experiences including social situations, and less likely to downplay conflicts (Costa & McCrae, 1992; LePine, 2003). This relational focus is expected to facilitate a positive group environment in groups high on openness.

Openness to experience is especially relevant to group performance in challenging conditions such as dynamic environments (LePine, 2003; LePine, Colquitt, & Erez, 2000), computer-mediated work settings (Colquitt, Hollenbeck, Ilgen, LePine, & Sheppard, 2002), and diverse groups (Homan et al., 2008). Openness is particularly relevant to working in a diverse team. Members of such teams are likely to have different viewpoints, attitudes, and ideas (and greater likelihood of conflicts) than members of homogeneous teams (Cox, Lobel, & McLeod, 1991; Homan et al., 2008; van Knippenberg et al., 2004). In general, research suggests that groups scoring highly on openness to experience tend to share more new ideas with their group members (Bond & Shiu, 1997). Ekehammar and Akrami (2003) demonstrated that openness to experience, more than any of the other four factors in the five-factor model, is related to beliefs about and attitudes toward diversity. Similarly, Flynn (2005) showed that people who have high levels of openness have more positive attitudes toward minority members than their low-scoring counterparts. High levels of group openness can help newly formed nationally diverse groups to compensate for their lack of other shared features; by promoting interpersonal citizenship behavior within the group, openness generates positive experiences of differences. Building on this research, we hypothesize as follows:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1 (H1): Group-level openness to experience will be positively related to group interpersonal citizenship behavior: (a) national diversity moderates the effect of group openness to experience on group interpersonal citizenship behavior and (b) nationally diverse groups will show a stronger positive relationship between group openness to experience and group interpersonal behavior than will nationally similar groups.

sec.title: Group Agreeableness
sec.p: Agreeableness is the desire to get along with others and have sympathy for their problems (Moynihan & Peterson, 2004). Agreeable individuals tend to make contributions that benefit those colleagues with whom they have enjoyed rewarding workplace relationships (i.e., OCB-I; Ilies, Fulmer, Spitzmuller, & Johnson, 2009). People scoring highly on agreeableness tend to be altruistic, acquiescent, trusting and helpful (McCrae & Costa, 1987). Agreeable people focus on their relationships and the quality of their interactions with others. Confronted with conflict or disagreement, they seek to restore social harmony and reduce within-group competition (Graziano, Hair, & Finch, 1997). Individuals scoring highly on agreeableness tend to make special efforts to promote social relationships by seeking or offering support (Hooker, Frazier, & Monahan, 1994; O’Brien & DeLongis, 1996) and avoiding confrontation (O’Brien & DeLongis, 1996). Moreover, individuals scoring highly on agreeableness tend to be rated as cooperative group members by their peers (Wagner, 1995; Wagner & Moch, 1986). They are motivated to maintain a positive social atmosphere (Bell, 2007) and excel at interpersonal facilitation (Hurtz & Donovan, 2000).

Being agreeable is a desirable trait for creating positive social interactions. Neuman and Wright (1999) found that at both individual and group levels agreeableness correlates with interpersonal skills. At the group level, group agreeableness predicts supervisor ratings of work-team performance as well as objective indicators of work-team accuracy and work completed (Neuman & Wright, 1999; Neuman, Wagner, & Christiansen, 1999). No empirical study has examined the effect of group-level agreeableness on group interpersonal citizenship behavior. Nonetheless, past theory and research provides a basis for expecting a relationship between them based on the prosocial motives and behaviors associated with agreeableness.

Agreeableness may be particularly critical for the effectiveness of performance in diverse groups. Diverse groups are more prone to experience conflicting social identities among their members as well as greater task and relational conflicts than are homogeneous groups (Williams & O’Reilly, 1998). Groups scoring higher on agreeableness should manage conflict better, as agreeableness affects a group’s capacity to create and maintain positive relationships among members. Such positive social interactions are expected to reduce both overt and latent bias among group members, increasing their likelihood of displaying interpersonal citizenship behavior. Therefore, we hypothesize as follows:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2 (H2): Group-level agreeableness will be positively related to group interpersonal citizenship behavior: (a) national diversity moderates the effect of group agreeableness on group interpersonal citizenship behavior and (b) nationally diverse groups will have a greater positive effect of group agreeableness on group interpersonal citizenship behavior than will nationally similar groups.

sec.title: Group Conscientiousness
sec.p: Conscientiousness is the tendency to be organized, purposeful, and responsible (Moynihan & Peterson, 2004). Individuals scoring highly on conscientiousness are more likely to perform well (Neuman & Wright, 1999) across a variety of situations (Barrick & Mount, 1991; Perrewe & Spector, 2002). Little research has examined the trait of group conscientiousness though; we expect a positive relationship with group interpersonal citizenship behavior.

The effect of group conscientiousness on interpersonal citizenship behavior is expected to be amplified in diverse groups given their association with greater conflict and weaker shared understandings regarding how to relate to each other, which goals to pursue and through what means (van Knippenberg & Schippers, 2007; Williams & O’Reilly, 1998). The larger potential for conflict in diverse groups creates greater benefits for those which act responsibility and reliably. National diversity can make it necessary for the group to be conscientious and to resolve problems that interfere with the task than might otherwise be the case in homogeneous groups. Acting strategically, and in an organized fashion, can help resolve the conflicts diverse groups more frequently experience. Therefore, we hypothesize as follows:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 3: Group-level conscientiousness will be positively related to group interpersonal citizenship behavior: (a) national diversity in groups moderates the relationship between group conscientiousness and group interpersonal behavior and (b) nationally diverse groups will have a greater positive effect of group conscientiousness on group interpersonal citizenship behavior than will nationally similar groups.

sec.title: Group Extraversion
sec.p: Group extraversion is the tendency to be assertive, active, and sociable. In jobs with a high degree of social interaction, a positive relationship is expected between extraversion and performance (Barrick & Mount, 1991; Mount, Barrick, & Stewart, 1998). However, there is also research that supports the opposite. For example, Barry and Stewart (1997) found that groups with high proportions of extraverted members could experience reduced cohesion and performance. The rationale is that a group with many extraverts may not work well together because they compete for dominance. Instead, these researchers suggest a curvilinear relationship between group extraversion and performance as discussed by Pierce and Aguinis (2011).

In this laboratory study, we propose that national diversity moderates the relationship between group extraversion and group interpersonal citizenship behavior in a positive direction. As members are assigned to groups and not selected based on personality, extreme scores on average extraversion are not expected. We posit that a high level of extraversion in a diverse group such as those studied here should help its members to display the sociability that promotes within-group interpersonal citizenship behavior. Extraversion is also related to feedback seeking whereby individuals obtain social information regarding how their behavior affects others (Krasman, 2010), an activity which can compensate for the lack of shared information characteristic of newly formed diverse groups. Thus, we expect that heterogeneous groups will benefit more from extraversion than homogeneous ones in promoting exchange of social information and active engagement in the group, thereby promoting group interpersonal citizenship behavior. Thus, we hypothesize as follows:

list-item.p: Hypotheses 4: Group-level extraversion will be positively related to group interpersonal citizenship behavior: (a) national diversity will moderate the effect group extraversion has on group interpersonal citizenship behavior and (b) nationally diverse groups will have a greater positive effect of extraversion on group interpersonal citizenship behavior than will nationally similar groups.

sec.title: Group Neuroticism
sec.p: Neuroticism is the tendency to experience negative emotions including fear, embarrassment, and guilt (Moynihan & Peterson, 2004). Individuals scoring highly on neuroticism are more likely to use emotion-focused strategies such as escape, avoidance, self-blame, and wishful thinking when confronting problems than those who are less neurotic. Neurotic individuals tend to behave in interpersonally antagonistic ways, coping with stress by hostile reactions, venting negative emotions (David & Suls, 1999; Gunthert, Cohen, & Armeli, 1999; O’Brien & DeLongis, 1996), and withdrawing from others (O’Brien & DeLongis, 1996). Groups scoring high on negative affect, a manifestation of neuroticism, tend to display less prosocial behavior than those with low negative affect (George, 1990). As such, the negative emotions associated with collective neuroticism impair member interactions, resulting in poorer group effectiveness.

However, when the group scores low on neuroticism, it is likely to be easier for members to work together and to be more effective. Individuals who are emotionally stable (e.g., secure, calm, and steady) are able to maintain healthy relationships, contribute to the team’s effort, and thereby enhance its performance (Hough, 1992; Mount, Barrick, & Stewart, 1998). For instance, a team composed of emotionally stable individuals might create a relaxed atmosphere that promotes cooperation and less disruptive behavior (Bell, 2007; Reilly, Lynn, & Aronson, 2002). In this regard, Hurtz and Donovan (2000) report positive effects from emotional stability across various job performance outcomes.

Groups higher on neuroticism tend to have difficulty resolving conflicts, to have poorer group member interactions, and to perform less well than their low neuroticism counterparts. Given that diversity can increase the potential for misunderstanding and conflict within groups and increase levels of negative emotions that group members experience (Shemla, Wegge, Kearney, & Schraub, 2010; van Knippenberg & Schippers, 2007; Williams & O’Reilly, 1998), neuroticism’s effects are likely to be exacerbated for heterogeneous groups. We therefore hypothesize as follows:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 5: Group-level neuroticism will be negatively related to group interpersonal citizenship behavior: (a) national diversity will moderate the effect of group neuroticism on group interpersonal citizenship behavior and (b) nationally diverse groups will show a more negative effect for group neuroticism on interpersonal citizenship behavior than will nationally similar groups.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The sample for this study was composed of 143 undergraduate students from a university in the Midwestern United States. All students were enrolled in a foundation business course and participated in exchange for course credits. Participants were on average 25 years old with a range between 20 and 60 years old; 60% were women; 37% were White, 26% Hispanic, 18% Asian, and 19% from other ethnic groups; 56% were born in the United States, and 44% elsewhere. Eighty-three percentage were employed full- or part-time.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: An experiment was conducted to test our hypotheses. It took place in a classroom setting using individual random assignment to newly formed groups differing in national diversity.

sec.title: Manipulation of National Diversity
sec.p: National diversity was manipulated by creating homogeneous groups with members born in the same country and heterogeneous groups with members born in different countries. There were 15 homogeneous groups, consisting of 61 students, 53 born in the United States, and 8 in Poland. There were 20 heterogeneous groups, consisting of 79 students, of which 24 were born in the United States and the rest elsewhere. In total, the study included 35 teams with either 4 or 5 members.

Groups were created using a two-step method. First, we created three separate pools: participants born in the United States, participants born in Poland, and participants born in other countries. Second, we randomly assigned individuals into heterogeneous groups, assigning one from each pool into groups until the smallest pool (participants born in other countries) was exhausted. We then randomly assigned the remaining students born in either the United States or Poland into homogeneous groups.

Groups were comparable (i.e., not statistically different) on other demographics including age and gender. We assigned 1 to denote similar groups and 2 for diverse groups (Cohen, Cohen, West, & Aiken, 2003).

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: All groups participated in the same course and its group project. The project involved presenting an oral case analysis and submitting a written report. In the 1st week, students’ demographic data were collected along with the Big Five personality traits. In the 2nd week, the groups were created. Interpersonal citizenship behavior was measured at week 15.

sec.title: Collective personality traits
sec.p: Collective personality was operationalized by averaging each Big Five personality trait at the group level. We used a short version of the Big Five (John, Donahue, & Kentle, 1991): openness to experience (10 items, α = .74), agreeableness (nine items, α = .73), conscientiousness (nine items, α = .61), extraversion (eight items, α = .79), and neuroticism (eight items, α = .79). It employed a 5-point Likert-type agreement scale. Internal consistency reliabilities (α) were similar to those in previous studies (LePine et al., 2000; Olson, 2007; Shackelford & Besser, 2007). Finally, within each group and for each personality factor, we aggregated the individual data at the group level. The interrater agreement indices (rwg) are 0.88 for openness to experience, 0.88 for agreeableness, 0.81 for conscientiousness, 0.87 for extraversion, and 0.83 for neuroticism (Cohen, Doveh, & Nahum-Shani, 2009). We also calculated two intraclass correlations—ICC(1) and ICC(2). ICC(1) values were 0.10 for openness to experience, 0.08 for agreeableness, 0.12 for conscientiousness, 0.13 for extraversion, and 0.02 for neuroticism; ICC(2) values were 0.31 for openness to experience, 0.26 for agreeableness, 0.35 for conscientiousness, 0.39 for extraversion, and 0.09 for neuroticism. The values of these intraclass correlations are typical in team research (Bliese, 2000; Cohen, Doveh, & Nahum-Shani, 2009) and in group personality research (Zoogah et al., 2010).

sec.title: Interpersonal citizenship behavior within the group
sec.p: Each individual rated fellow group members in terms of interpersonal citizenship. Four items from the scale developed by Settoon and Mossholder (2002) were used: (a) Listens to you when you have something to say, (b) Takes time to listen to your point of view, (c) Takes a personal interest in your point of view, and (d) Tries to help you up when you have a problem expressing your point of view. The group-level measure was computed by averaging all members’ perceptions of one another’s behavior. Internal consistency reliability (α) was .94. To evaluate the appropriateness of aggregation, we calculated interrater agreement (rwg(j); James, Demaree, & Wolf, 1984) and two intraclass correlations—ICC(1) and ICC(2)—as well as an F-test associated with ICC(1), to capture interrater reliability/consistency. Interrater agreement for interpersonal citizenship behavior was 0.88, above the 0.70 benchmark proposed by James et al. (1984). ICC(1) and ICC(2) values were 0.57 and 0.84 (F = 3.64, p < .05), consistent with values typical in team research (Bliese, 2000; Cohen, Doveh, & Nahum-Shani, 2009).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Descriptive statistics and zero-order correlations are shown in Table 1. All group-level Big Five traits were related to group citizenship behavior (p < .01), per H1 to H5a. Diversity was not related to group interpersonal citizenship behavior. A set of hierarchical regressions tested the five hypotheses. Statistics for the initial regressions indicated multicollinearity between the interaction term and the independent variables. Variance inflation factors (VIF) over a value of 10 are generally considered problematic (Neter & Wasserman, 1985). The VIFs associated with the interaction terms for this analysis ranged from 22 to 89. Thus, the independent variables were centered following the procedures recommended by Aiken and West (1991). Independent variables were centered by subtracting the mean from each observation’s value. The variances in group personality were controlled as advised by Klein and Kozlowski (2000a, 2000b).

sec.title: Hypotheses Testing
sec.p: H1 addressed the role of group openness to experience. Its direct effect on group interpersonal citizenship behavior is significant (β = 0.32, p < .01) consistent with H1a (Table 2). Its interaction with diversity is also significant (β = 0.24, p < .01) and improves the model (ΔR2 = .05, ΔF = 1.20, p < .01) supporting H1b. To fully understand the nature of the interaction, it was graphed (Figure 1). Following Cohen et al. (2003), we specified the high and low values as plus and minus one standard deviation from the mean. The graph illustrates that the positive relationship between openness to experience and group interpersonal citizenship behavior is stronger for diverse groups (β = 0.45, p < .01) than for similar groups (β = 0.02, not significant). H1a and H1b are thus both supported.

sec.p: Similar analyses were conducted for all remaining hypotheses. H2 dealt with group agreeableness. Its direct effect on group interpersonal citizenship behavior is significant (β = 0.49, p < .01), consistent with H2a. Its interaction with diversity is also significant (β = 0.27, p < .01, Table 3) and improves the model (ΔR2 = .07, ΔF = 1.04, p < .01). The effect is stronger for diverse groups (β = 0.62, p < .01) than for similar groups (β = 0.23, not significant; Figure 2). H2a and H2b thus are both supported.

sec.p: H4 addressed group extraversion. Group extraversion is positively related to group intercitizenship behavior (β = 0.35, p < .01). Its interaction with diversity is significant (β = 2.66, p < .01) as shown in Table 5, and the model was improved (ΔR2 = .07, ΔF = 2.03, p < .01). Figure 3 shows that this effect is stronger in nationally diverse groups (β = 0.78, p < .01) than for similar groups (β = 0.01, not significant). H4a and H4b are both supported.

sec.p: The results for H5 are more complex. The direct effect of neuroticism is not significant. sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As hypothesized, collective personality traits supporting constructive interpersonal interactions were positively related to group interpersonal citizenship behavior. These traits include openness to experience, extraversion, conscientiousness, and agreeableness. The only trait associated with negative interpersonal relationships, neuroticism, had no direct effect. Moreover, of the five interactions hypothesized, four were significant. Group openness to experience, group agreeableness, group extraversion, and group neuroticism all interacted with national diversity in effecting group interpersonal citizenship behavior. These relationships underscore the collective functioning of traits previously attributed to individuals alone and the advantages they bring to a major group challenge: promoting quality outcomes in groups where members differ in their social identities. In this discussion, we first develop some of the distinct implications associated with some of our findings. Then, we address the relevance of our findings for theory and research, and for practice. We end with a discussion of this study’s limitations.

sec.title: Implications of Specific Findings
sec.p: Although the majority of findings hew closely to the theory and research on which our hypotheses were based, several results were unanticipated. First, collective conscientiousness had a direct effect on group citizenship behavior, but no interaction with diversity. Given the task focus of conscientiousness we suspect that high levels of this trait in a group focus attention on interpersonal behaviors that enable results and deliverables. In the context of our citizenship measure, this would mean seeking to understand what others have to say about the task. Less attention may have been given to making fellow members feel comfortable or facilitating an enjoyable social climate. Thus, conscientiousness can affect the aspects of citizenship behavior that support the group’s work, but may not lead to more interpersonal concern and interest in the social welfare of members, factors that might compensate for some of the social challenges associated with national diversity. However, group conscientiousness might be a more plausible moderator of the relationship between diversity and task performance, where special attention to others’ points of view in a diverse group might facilitate task success. Conscientiousness has been found to reflect a generalized behavioral tendency across a variety of situations (e.g., Lee, Ashton, & Shin, 2005; Mount, Ilies, & Johnson, 2006). Thus, for example, although agreeableness with its focus on interpersonal relationships might be closely related to OCB-I, conscientiousness might lead to broader contributions in the form of task performance and OCB-O rather than to OCB-I. It is also possible that its lower reliability contributed to the lack of an interaction in this study.

Group neuroticism had no direct effect on group citizenship behavior, but quite a distinct and divergent interaction with diversity. We suspect that neuroticism’s interactions in opposing directions for diverse and similar groups cancelled out any direct effect. Moreover, though diverse groups manifest the negative effect of group neuroticism on group-level citizenship, the opposite is true for homogeneous groups. In effect, collective neuroticism in nationally homogeneous groups was associated with members paying close attention to the views of others, the focus of our citizenship measure. Collective neuroticism coincides with negative emotions, a state that the presence of dissimilar others may amplify. In contrast, a group high on neuroticism may experience reduced anxieties while working on an assigned task with similar others. Insofar as neuroticism is expressed under conditions of conflict, threat, and challenge, such a situation may have been viewed as less stressful relative to other group work in the university, where diversity is the norm. At the same time, the divergent effect of neuroticism on the groups studied here call attention to the potential for nonlinear effects as noted in our theory section with regard to extraversion (cf. Pierce & Aguinis, 2011). In the field where self-selection of members into groups can in part be based on similarity in attributes, nonlinear effects need to be considered. This may be especially true for traits that otherwise have positive impact on group outcomes, but at the extreme may be considered “too much of a good thing.” Although neuroticism might not be construed as a good thing under most conditions, the remaining Big Five traits, particularly extraversion, can impair group functioning at extreme levels.

sec.title: Theoretical and Research Implications
sec.p: This study suggests that collective personality plays a role in both group citizenship behavior and in the effects group diversity has on citizenship behavior. The group personality traits we examined go beyond those typically studied, broadening our knowledge of how collective traits may compensate or exacerbate the effects of cultural diversity on group effectiveness. Indeed, only limited research has examined the role of various collective personality traits in diversity’s impact on group effectiveness (Bell, 2007; Homan et al., 2008; Kearney et al., 2009). As pointed out by Kearney et al. (2009), “the two lines of team composition research, one examining team diversity and one examining mean levels of team member personality, have hitherto been mostly distinct” (p. 581). With the exception of Homan et al. (2008) and Kearney et al. (2009), other studies have not integrated these lines of team composition research.

Importantly, we focused on collective personality in newly formed groups. In such settings, the traits individuals bring to the group are more likely to provide a basis for their collective interactions. In new or emergent situations, aggregated individual traits provide a collective resource to help structure and organize otherwise weak, behaviorally ambiguous situations (Mischel, 2004; Weick, 1995). In more established groups, as in the retail store units studied by Hofmann and Jones (2005), collective personality is likely to be represented by shared ways of behaving developed by the group over time. In the latter case, it is appropriate to assess collective personality via a referent shift (Chan, 1998) such that members rate the extent to which the group itself manifests the traits reflected in personality indicators such as the Big Five. In our study, aggregated individual attributes reflect the emergent nature of personality. Future research might investigate how the initial personality traits collectively present in emergent groups might relate to subsequent formation of traits where the group itself is the referent.

The collective personality traits examined here can be conceptualized in terms of their implications for relationships within groups. In particular, openness to experience, agreeableness, and (low) neuroticism are all closely related to the way people react to differences between themselves and others. Such traits are considered essential for building healthy team relationships and developing a more effective group. Relationship-focused personality traits aim at maintaining and regulating social relationships (Kramer, 1993; O’Brien & DeLongis, 1996). Considering the likelihood of conflict in diverse groups, these traits may be useful in reducing conflict, promoting functional ways of dealing with it, and increasing their performance, especially when newly formed.

Other types of collective traits may also be relevant to group functioning. These include propensity to trust (Rotter, 1980), goal orientation (VandeWalle, 1997), empathy (Davis, 1983), and social dominance (Pratto, Sidanius, Stallworth, & Malle, 1994). Similarly, some collective characteristics not personality based on themselves also may affect within-group social behavior. For example, collective intelligence, though not strongly correlated with the average or maximum individual intelligence of group members, is correlated with their average social sensitivity and equality in their conversational turn-taking (Woolley-Williams et al., 2010). More systematic attention is warranted regarding the effects of collective traits on group and organizational outcomes.

Last, researchers (Flynn, 2005; Strauss, Connerley, & Ammermann, 2003) have argued that individual differences are related to attitudes about diversity in teams. Nonetheless, previous studies have emphasized primarily how personality traits predict intergroup bias and stereotyping at the individual level (Homan et al., 2008). Our findings indicate that group-level personality may also be important to understanding bias and stereotyping as well as how to overcome it.

sec.title: Practical Implications
sec.p: Extensive research has shown that various standardized selection instruments, especially cognitive ability tests, can have adverse impact on minorities in the hiring process (Arvey & Landon, 1992; Brown & Day, 2006). As mentioned by Gelfand, Nishii, Raver, and Schneider (2005) “the best way to combat discrimination in selection is . . . to use noncognitive measure such as personality and integrity tests when possible” (p. 101). In line with this reasoning, the present study suggests that selecting group members in a fashion that promotes collective openness to experience, agreeableness, extraversion, and/or low neuroticism may aid in forming effective new teams.

At the same time, where such a tactic is difficult to use, or if a team is known to lack such traits, a recent study (Homan et al., 2008) suggests a possible alternative. It advises strengthening the group’s collective identity to downplay differences between members. Alternatively, advocating prodiversity beliefs can reinforce group performance and enhance the information group members share with each other (Homan et al., 2008; van Knippenberg et al., 2004).

In dealing with dysfunctional collective personalities such as high neuroticism, O’Brien and DeLongis (1996) suggest that certain coping strategies can reduce personal distress and minimize damage to interpersonal relationships. It might help to support the group in engaging in problem solving and practicing empathy to enhance their relationships. Indeed, the high citizenship behavior we observe in homogeneous groups high on neuroticism suggests that interventions to reduce negative emotions can yield positive outcomes in highly neurotic groups.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: This study is not without limitations. First, our sample was composed of undergraduate student teams. Groups were relatively homogeneous on some demographics such as age with most participants ranging from 20 to 30 years old. Thus, replication and extension of our findings to field settings would be useful.

Second, the study used peer ratings of group interpersonal citizenship behavior. Although not as subjective as previous studies that rely only on self-report measures (Podsakoff, MacKenzie, Paine, & Bacharach, 2000), future research would be enhanced by an objective measure of group citizenship. Task performance should also be assessed given that effects of group personality traits on group outcomes may vary depending on the nature of the task.

The third limitation is a possible weakness in the cultural diversity manipulation. Participants’ categorization processes may have been weakly triggered by this study’s cultural diversity condition because of the highly diverse nature of the university’s student body. Unfortunately, a manipulation check for assessing individuals’ perception of cultural diversity was not used. Nonetheless, four out of the five diversity interactions we tested were significant suggesting that the diversity manipulation did indeed trigger the categorization process. Still, by being exposed to a high level of cultural diversity every day, our participants may have been less reactive to national diversity than might be expected in other settings. Finally, diversity takes many forms. Our findings are specific to national diversity.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study suggests that diverse groups may outperform homogeneous groups on interpersonal citizenship behaviors when members of diverse groups are highly relational in their interpersonal styles. At the same time, diverse groups are even more impaired when their members manifest antisocial orientations such as high levels of neuroticism and negative emotions. Such effects may be particularly likely in new or emergent groups where collective structures guiding member actions have not yet emerged.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Marie-Élène Roberge is an assistant professor of management at Northeastern Illinois University, United States. She received a PhD in labor and human resource management from Fisher College of Business, Ohio State University. Her research is about managing diversity in organizations and understanding individual and group behaviors in the workplace.

Qiumei Jane Xu is an assistant professor of management at Northeastern Illinois University, United States. She received a PhD in management from the Paul Merage School of Business, University of California, Irvine. She has conducted research on diversity, organizational citizenship behavior, and employee development.

Denise M. Rousseau is H. J. Heinz II University professor of organizational behavior at Carnegie Mellon University, United States, in the Heinz College of Public Policy, Information, and Management, Tepper School of Business. She has degrees in psychology and anthropology from the University of California at Berkeley.
